messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> That means we have to type an extra character when we type, something
> pretty unnatural.

Well, you get to decide whether x+y defaults to ligaturing or to not
ligaturing, but there has to be some way to signal the difference.
So it's either type a key to trigger ligaturing or type a key to
suppress ligaturing -- your choice.

> Also, that means letters are dependent on the ligature
> table, which may or may not be read by certain applications. For
> example, I've come across only two applications that read in my kerning
> table, TeX and Indesign. Word doesn't, OO doesn't, none of the browsers
> do. So I don't want to be dependent on a ligature table in order for a
> certain character to appear. If we are so dependent, surely we will
> become frustrated when we are typing something and we can't get what we
> want.

Kerning's a more advanced feature than ligaturing. Since you mention
Word, I assume you're on Windows, and I don't know much about rendering
on Windows.

--
But you, Wormtongue, you have done what you could for your true master. Some
reward you have earned at least. Yet Saruman is apt to overlook his bargains.
I should advise you to go quickly and remind him, lest he forget your faithful
service. --Gandalf John Cowan <cowan@...>
